title: Final Paper
text: Preface

title: 1  Introduction
text:
2 Study Information
1. Assess the relationship between different factors (intensity, involvement, and technicality) and popularity of songs.
We will use spotify data from the TidyTuesday dataset.
Table 4.1 shows a sample of the variables we have added for analysis:

Summary
Test

1 + 1

[1] 2
References

title: 1  Introduction
text:
2.1 Hypotheses

2.1.1 Hypothesis 1 (Brooke):
From a factor analysis of several variables in the Spotify data, three factors emerged that describe the various components of the songs. It is hypothesized that both the intensity and involvement factors will predict song popularity such that the higher the factor score, the more likely the the song will have a higher popularity score (over and above the effects of the other factor scores). The third factor, technicality, will not significantly predict song popularity.
song_popularity = b0 + b1_intensity + b2_involvement + b3_technicality [all predictors are continuous]


2.1.2 Hypothesis 2 (Sarah):
I hypothesize that song length will predict track type (song or not) but will not predict whether a song is both live and acoustic. For the relationship between track length and track type, I expect that longer tracks are less likely to be a song. I hypothesize that covariates (tempo, loudness, genre) would not affect the outcome.
p(song) = b0 + b1_length (+ b2_tempo + b3_loudness + b4_genre) (where genre is categorical, song is binary, and the rest of the variables in the model are continuous)
p(liv_acoust) = b0 + b1_length (+ b2_tempo + b3_loudness + b4_genre) (where genre is categorical, liv_acoust is binary, and the rest of the variables in the model are continuous)

title: 1  Introduction
text:
5.1 Study Design
Brooke: Part 1 of this study was based off of Brooke’s imagination rather than existing literature. The design. More details regarding the specifics of the dataset can be obtained from TidyTuesday.
Sarah: Part 2 consists of the same data as part 1. Specifics of the dataset can be found at the above address.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
6.1 Explanation of Existing Data
Brooke: the data has only been accessed thus far to complete a factor analysis of a subset of the existing variables of the Spotify dataset. Beyond the creation of factor scores, no summary statistics containing the outcome variable have been examined.
Sarah: Summary statistics have not been assessed on this data yet. This data has only been used to generate new variables of interest based on the existing data. The new variables are length, song, and liv_acoust.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
6.2 Data Collection Procedures
See the TidyTuesday webpage for a detailed description of how this data was collected and compiled.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
6.3 Sample Size
The sample size of Part 1 of this study is 32,833. This number was obtained based on the number of factor scores that were created.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
6.4 Sample Size Rationale
Brooke: The sample size was constrained to the existing observations in the dataset (secondary data analysis).

title: 1  Introduction
text:
7.1 Manipulated Variables
Brooke: See attached document (“Homework3.pdf”) with code and descriptions for the factor analysis that was conducted to obtain predictor variables.
Homework3.pdf
Sarah: The attached document “salas_sarah_HW3.html” describes the new variables generated in the dataset. The variable “length” is continuous and measured in minutes. The variable “song” is binary a denotes whether a track is likely a song. The variable “liv_acoust” is binary and denotes whether a track is both live and acoustic.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
7.2 Measured Variables
Brooke: The three factors have the following variables: Factor One: 1) energy, 2) loudness 3) acousticness, 4) liveness. Factor Two: 1) danceability, 2) valence, 3) speechiness, 4) tempo, 5) instrumentalness, Factor Three: 1) mode, 2) key.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
8.1 Statistical models
Brooke: I will use a model comparison approach to test the following model: song_popularity = b0 + b1_intensity + b2_involvement + b3_technicality [all predictors are continuous]
Sarah: I will use logistic regression with nested models to assess two relationships (1) the relationship between track length and being a song and (2) the relationship between track length and being both live and acoustic. For 1 and 2, I will run models with just the main variables of interest then run new models with the added covariates.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
8.2 Transformations
Brooke: Please see Homework 3 attachment for a detailed description of the conducted transformations (i.e., factor scores). No other transformations will be conducted in this dataset.
Sarah: There are no transformations expected for this analysis

title: 1  Introduction
text:
8.3 Missing data
Brooke: For the purposes of this project, I will just drop any observations (songs) that do not have factor scores.
Sarah: Should there be missing observations for the variables of interest, these will not be included in the analysis. Large amounts of missing data will be assessed for any systemic patterns.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
8.4 Exploratory Analysis
Brooke: The only exploratory analysis that was or will be conducted was factor analysis, which was described in the Homework 3 attachment.
Sarah: Exploratory analysis will examine any correlations between the measures for song, live, and acoustic along with length. Correlations will also be found between the two outcome variables and tempo and loudness.




Tabachnick, Barbara G., Linda S. Fidell, and Jodie B. Ullman. 2019. Using Multivariate Statistics. Seventh edition. NY, NY: Pearson.

title: 2  Chapter 2
text:
2.1 Brooke
Description of factors
The three factors have the following variables:
Factor One: 1) energy, 2) loudness 3) acousticness, 4) liveness.
Factor Two: 1) danceability, 2) valence, 3) speechiness, 4) tempo, 5) instrumentalness,
Factor Three: 1) mode, 2) key.
From this, I’m going to give the factors different names that are more descriptive than PA1-PA3. Factor One seems to describe the intensity of a song and a measurable amount of property, so I’ll rename Factor One to pa1_intensity (pa = principal axis and 1 = originally factor 1). Factor Two seems to describe level of involvement, which may be a little bit of a stretch, but involvement meaning the extent to which singers, instruments, and movement (i.e., dancing) contribute to a song. I’ll rename Factor Two to pa2_involvement. Finally, Factor Three is pretty basic and describe very technical aspects of songs, so I’ll rename Factor Three to pa3_technicality.

title: 2  Chapter 2
text:
2.2 Sarah
Table 1: Caption Variable Name Variable Type Variable Description X integer Duration of song in minutes length numeric Whether the track is a song song numeric Whether the track is both live and acoustic




Peng, Chao-Ying Joanne, Kuk Lida Lee, and Gary M. Ingersoll. 2002. “An Introduction to Logistic Regression Analysis and Reporting.” The Journal of Educational Research 96 (1): 3–14. https://doi.org/10.1080/00220670209598786.

title: 3  Chapter 3
text: 3.1 Brooke

title: 3  Chapter 3
text:
3.2 Background

3.2.1 Loading packages

library(tidyverse)
library(psych)
library(GPArotation)
library(psy)
library(plotrix)
library(FactoMineR)



3.2.2 Loading spotify data

d <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2020-01-21')$spotify_songs


    Downloading file 1 of 1: `spotify_songs.csv`

names(d)

 [1] "track_id"                 "track_name"              
 [3] "track_artist"             "track_popularity"        
 [5] "track_album_id"           "track_album_name"        
 [7] "track_album_release_date" "playlist_name"

[17] "speechiness"              "acousticness"            
[19] "instrumentalness"         "liveness"                
[21] "valence"                  "tempo"                   
[23] "duration_ms"             




3.2.3 New variables using Spotify data
When thinking about creating three new variables from this Spotify data, I’m curious to know whether there are any latent factors within them. I’m going to run an exploratory factor analysis (EFA) to find out, and then create factor scores based on the latent dimensions that I find.

3.2.3.1 Correlation matrix
Before running the EFA, first I’ll look at a correlation matrix to see whether any of the variables have reasonable correlations.

cor_matrix <- d %>% 
  select(danceability, energy, key, loudness, mode, speechiness, acousticness, instrumentalness, liveness, valence, tempo, duration_ms) %>% 
  cor(use = "pairwise.complete.obs")

cor_matrix %>% 
  round(2) %>% 
  knitr::kable()

Looking at the correlation matrix, it seems that loudness and energy are highly positively correlated (r = .68), valence and danceability are positively correlated (r = .33), acousticness and energy are negatively correlated (r = -.54), and acousticness and loudness are negatively correlated (r = -.36). There are a few other smaller correlations, but these are the main ones. I wonder if there could be two factors that relate to how upbeat or chill a song is.
In terms of outliers, it looks like duration in ms, mode, and key aren’t really correlated with much, but mode and key are correlated with each other. I think I’m going to eliminate duration in ms because I’m not sure that relates a ton to the other variables. I’ll keep mode and key! (Also I’m aware this is pretty arbitrary but I’m just going with it haha)

# removing the outlier (duration_ms) from the correlation matrix
cor_matrix2 <- d %>% 
  select(danceability, energy, key, loudness, mode, speechiness, acousticness, instrumentalness, liveness, valence, tempo) %>% 
  cor(use = "pairwise.complete.obs")

title: 3  Chapter 3
text:
3.3 Sarah
I created three new variables in this data. Table 1 shows the new variables created from the existing Spotify data which includes song length (in minutes), whether the track is a song, and whether the track is both live and acoustic.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
3.1 Our hypotheses are:

3.1.1 Hypothesis 1 (Brooke):
From a factor analysis of several variables in the Spotify data, three factors emerged that describe the various components of the songs. It is hypothesized that both the intensity and involvement factors will predict song popularity such that the higher the factor score, the more likely the the song will have a higher popularity score (over and above the effects of the other factor scores). The third factor, technicality, will not significantly predict song popularity.
song_popularity = b0 + b1_intensity + b2_involvement + b3_technicality [all predictors are continuous]


3.1.2 Hypothesis 2 (Sarah):
I hypothesize that song length will predict track type (song or not) but will not predict whether a song is both live and acoustic. For the relationship between track length and track type, I expect that longer tracks are less likely to be a song. I hypothesize that covariates (tempo, loudness, genre) would not affect the outcome.
p(song) = b0 + b1_length (+ b2_tempo + b3_loudness + b4_genre) (where genre is categorical, song is binary, and the rest of the variables in the model are continuous)
p(liv_acoust) = b0 + b1_length (+ b2_tempo + b3_loudness + b4_genre) (where genre is categorical, liv_acoust is binary, and the rest of the variables in the model are continuous)

title: 2  Methods: Brooke’s Spotify data variable creation
text:
2.1 Background
I created three new variables from the Spotify data. See Table 2.1 for descriptives of the three new variables. Below outlines the steps that were taken to create them.
Specifically, I was curious to know whether there were any latent factors in the data. To examine this, I ran an exploratory factor analysis (EFA) and created factor scores based on those latent dimensions.

title: 2  Background
text:
2.1 Loading packages

library(tidyverse)
library(psych)
library(GPArotation)
library(psy)
library(plotrix)
library(FactoMineR)

title: 2  Background
text:
2.2 Loading spotify data

d <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2020-01-21')$spotify_songs


    Downloading file 1 of 1: `spotify_songs.csv`

[19] "instrumentalness"         "liveness"

[23] "duration_ms"

title: 2  Methods: Brooke’s Spotify data variable creation

2.2 New variables using Spotify data
When thinking about creating three new variables from this Spotify data, I’m curious to know whether there are any latent factors within them. I’m going to run an exploratory factor analysis (EFA) to find out, and then create factor scores based on the latent dimensions that I find.

2.2.1 Correlation matrix
Before running the EFA, first I’ll look at a correlation matrix to see whether any of the variables have reasonable correlations.

cor_matrix <- d %>% 
  select(danceability, energy, key, loudness, mode, speechiness, acousticness, instrumentalness, liveness, valence, tempo, duration_ms) %>% 
  cor(use = "pairwise.complete.obs")

cor_matrix %>% 
  round(2) %>% 
  knitr::kable()

Looking at the correlation matrix, it seems that loudness and energy are highly positively correlated (r = .68), valence and danceability are positively correlated (r = .33), acousticness and energy are negatively correlated (r = -.54), and acousticness and loudness are negatively correlated (r = -.36). There are a few other smaller correlations, but these are the main ones. I wonder if there could be two factors that relate to how upbeat or chill a song is.
In terms of outliers, it looks like duration in ms, mode, and key aren’t really correlated with much, but mode and key are correlated with each other. I think I’m going to eliminate duration in ms because I’m not sure that relates a ton to the other variables. I’ll keep mode and key! (Also I’m aware this is pretty arbitrary but I’m just going with it haha)

# removing the outlier (duration_ms) from the correlation matrix
cor_matrix2 <- d %>% 
  select(danceability, energy, key, loudness, mode, speechiness, acousticness, instrumentalness, liveness, valence, tempo) %>% 
  cor(use = "pairwise.complete.obs")



2.2.2 Extracting factors
I’m going to use factor analysis to analyze covariance (rather than unique variance or error variance). I suspect there could be three factors, with one related songs that are upbeat, another with chill song characteristics, and a third with mode and key together (I’m not really a music person but maybe those have to do with the logistics/creation of a song).
To determine how many factors to extract, I’m going to keep factors with an

eigen(cor_matrix2)$values

 [1] 2.1522908 1.5192814 1.1795078 1.0892864 0.9786859 0.9729357 0.8700836
 [8] 0.8068100 0.6375606 0.5688131 0.2247446


Interestingly, there are four factors with an eigenvalue greater than 1. Let’s look at a Scree plot as well.

VSS.scree(cor_matrix2)




Hmmm, it almost looks like there could be a couple elbows here. I guess one elbow could be the third factor, but the more obvious elbow is the fourth factor. Maybe I will try a solution with two factors and also four factors to see how well it fits.


2.2.3 Factor rotation

2.2.3.1 Four factor solution
I think it’s fine for the factors to be correlated, so I’ll use an oblique rotation and retain 4 factors. Based on the eigenvalues alone (and kind of the Scree plot), this seems to be the best fit.

# running the factor analysis
fa4 <- fa(r = cor_matrix2,      # Correlation matrix input
          nfactors = 4,         # Number of factors retained
          rotate = "oblimin",   # Type of rotation used, "oblimin" for "oblique"
          covar = FALSE,        # Type of input matrix (we're inputting a correlation matrix)
          fm = "pa",            # principal axis factoring
          max.iter = 1000)      # increasing the maximum number of iterations than the default     

Warning in fa.stats(r = r, f = f, phi = phi, n.obs = n.obs, np.obs = np.obs, :
The estimated weights for the factor scores are probably incorrect.  Try a
different factor score estimation method.


Warning in fac(r = r, nfactors = nfactors, n.obs = n.obs, rotate = rotate, : An
ultra-Heywood case was detected.  Examine the results carefully




2.2.3.2 Two factor solution
Based on the Scree plot, I think I’d also like to see what a two factor solution looks like. Again, I think it’s fine for the factors to be correlated, so I’ll use an oblique rotation and retain 2 factors.

# running the factor analysis
fa2 <- fa(r = cor_matrix2,      # Correlation matrix input
          nfactors = 2,         # Number of factors retained
          rotate = "oblimin",   # Type of rotation used, "oblimin" for "oblique"
          covar = FALSE,        # Type of input matrix (we're inputting a correlation matrix)
          fm = "pa",            # principal axis factoring
          max.iter = 500)       # increasing the maximum number of iterations than the default        

Warning in fa.stats(r = r, f = f, phi = phi, n.obs = n.obs, np.obs = np.obs, :
The estimated weights for the factor scores are probably incorrect.  Try a
different factor score estimation method.


Warning in fac(r = r, nfactors = nfactors, n.obs = n.obs, rotate = rotate, : An
ultra-Heywood case was detected.  Examine the results carefully




2.2.3.3 Three factor solution
Okay well now I’m going down a rabbit hole because I need 3 variables to complete this homework assignment so I’m hoping that a two factor solution is not the best one. I’m going to run 3 factors just in case cuz what the heck.

# running the factor analysis
fa3 <- fa(r = cor_matrix2,      # Correlation matrix input
          nfactors = 3,         # Number of factors retained
          rotate = "oblimin",   # Type of rotation used, "oblimin" for "oblique"
          covar = FALSE,        # Type of input matrix (we're inputting a correlation matrix)
          fm = "pa",            # principal axis factoring
          max.iter = 500)       # increasing the maximum number of iterations than the default        

Warning in fa.stats(r = r, f = f, phi = phi, n.obs = n.obs, np.obs = np.obs, :
The estimated weights for the factor scores are probably incorrect.  Try a
different factor score estimation method.


Warning in fac(r = r, nfactors = nfactors, n.obs = n.obs, rotate = rotate, : An
ultra-Heywood case was detected.  Examine the results carefully





2.2.4 Interpreting findings
Now that I’ve run 2, 3, and 4 factor solutions, I’m going to look at and interpret the results to see what is best. Typically we consider a strong enough link to be >0.30. I’ll also look at whether there’s any variables that load onto multiple factors or neither factors (the first of which being more problematic). Finally, we’ll look at interpretability and whether the factor extraction makes sense.
Also, h^2 values represent the proportion of the variance in a variable that is predictable from the factors underlying it. If communality values equal or exceed 1, there is a problem (too little data, wrong number of factors extracted). A very low communality value for a variable indicates that this variable is an “outlier variable,” because it can’t be predicted from the factors extracted.

2.2.4.1 Two factor solution

# 2 factor solution
print(fa2, sort = T)

Factor Analysis using method =  pa
Call: fa(r = cor_matrix2, nfactors = 2, rotate = "oblimin", covar = FALSE, 
    max.iter = 500, fm = "pa")
Standardized loadings (pattern matrix) based upon correlation matrix
                 item   PA1   PA2     h2     u2 com
energy              2  1.02 -0.02 1.0430 -0.043 1.0
loudness            4  0.67  0.07 0.4475  0.552 1.0
acousticness        7 -0.53 -0.02 0.2817  0.718 1.0
liveness            9  0.14 -0.11 0.0327  0.967 1.9
danceability        1 -0.01  0.85 0.7293  0.271 1.0
valence            10  0.13  0.40 0.1687  0.831 1.2
speechiness         6  0.00  0.20 0.0383  0.962 1.0
tempo              11  0.15 -0.17 0.0540  0.946 2.0
instrumentalness    8 -0.05 -0.11 0.0148  0.985 1.3
mode                5 -0.01 -0.07 0.0052  0.995 1.1
key                 3  0.01  0.04 0.0014  0.999 1.1

                       PA1  PA2
SS loadings           1.83 0.99
Proportion Var        0.17 0.09
Cumulative Var        0.17 0.26
Proportion Explained  0.65 0.35
Cumulative Proportion 0.65 1.00

      PA1   PA2
PA1  1.00 -0.05
PA2 -0.05  1.00

Mean item complexity =  1.2
Test of the hypothesis that 2 factors are sufficient.

df null model =  55  with the objective function =  1.47
df of  the model are 34  and the objective function was  0.23 

The root mean square of the residuals (RMSR) is  0.04 
The df corrected root mean square of the residuals is  0.06 

Fit based upon off diagonal values = 0.92

fa.diagram(fa2)




Here we can see that energy has a very high h^2 value that exceeds 1! This could be because it’s very likely that energy in and of itself is a factor, and many of the other variables could constitute energy. Also, mode and key have extremely low h^2 values, so maybe I could consider excluding them. Finally, there are a few variables that don’t really load well onto either factor.


2.2.4.2 Three factor solution

# 3 factor solution
print(fa3, sort = T)

Factor Analysis using method =  pa
Call: fa(r = cor_matrix2, nfactors = 3, rotate = "oblimin", covar = FALSE, 
    max.iter = 500, fm = "pa")

fa.diagram(fa3)




Here, energy still has a very high h^2 value and the only variables that really load onto the third factor are mode and key, which was predicted from the correlation matrix. Compared to the 2 factor solution, the three factor seems to be a better fit. On factor one is energy, loudness, and acousticness. Liveness and tempo kind of load onto both factors. For factor two, there is danceability, valence, speechiness, and instrumentalness. So far I think this solution is better than the two factor solution!


2.2.4.3 Four factor solution

# 4 factor solution
print(fa4, sort = T)

Factor Analysis using method =  pa
Call: fa(r = cor_matrix2, nfactors = 4, rotate = "oblimin", covar = FALSE, 
    max.iter = 1000, fm = "pa")
Standardized loadings (pattern matrix) based upon correlation matrix
                 item   PA1   PA2   PA3   PA4    h2     u2 com

valence            10  0.22  0.11 -0.14  0.00 0.077  0.923 2.2

The df corrected root mean square of the residuals is  0.03 

Fit based upon off diagonal values = 0.99

fa.diagram(fa4)




Looking at the four factor solution, the h^2 value is still high for energy, but now also very high for instrumentalness (1.56) and danceability (2.42). I don’t think these factors are as interpretable. Also I think I shouldn’t put a ton more effort into finding the best solution at this point!!



2.2.5 Conclusion
I’ve decided based on interpretibility and factor loadings, I’m going to go with the three factor solution. This also works best with the assingment :) Also, I forgot to note this, but it looks like 30% of the variance is being explained by 3 factors.


2.2.6 Factor scores
Next I’m going to create factor scores from the 3 factor model, which are estimates of the scores participants (songs in this case) would have received on each of the factors had the factors been measured directly. Factor scores weigh individual variables differently from one sample to the next and depend in part on the “other” variables that were included in the factor analysis.

# creating factor scores for the 3 factor model
f_scores <- d %>% 
  select(danceability, energy, key, loudness, mode, speechiness, acousticness, instrumentalness, liveness, valence, tempo) %>% 
  factor.scores(fa3, method = "Thurstone") # Thurstone method involves weighting

# cbind binds a column onto the end of it
d <- cbind(d, f_scores$scores) # just keeping the scores themselves



# checking work
names(d)

 [1] "track_id"                 "track_name"              
 [3] "track_artist"             "track_popularity"        
 [5] "track_album_id"           "track_album_name"        
 [7] "track_album_release_date" "playlist_name"           
 [9] "playlist_id"              "playlist_genre"          
[11] "playlist_subgenre"        "danceability"            
[13] "energy"                   "key"                     
[15] "loudness"                 "mode"                    
[17] "speechiness"              "acousticness"            
[19] "instrumentalness"         "liveness"                
[21] "valence"                  "tempo"                   
[23] "duration_ms"              "PA1"                     
[25] "PA2"                      "PA3"                     


We’ve got PA1, PA2, and PA3 stuck on the end which are the factor scores!


2.2.7 Description of factors
The three factors have the following variables:
Factor One: 1) energy, 2) loudness 3) acousticness, 4) liveness.
Factor Two: 1) danceability, 2) valence, 3) speechiness, 4) tempo, 5) instrumentalness,
Factor Three: 1) mode, 2) key.
From this, I’m going to give the factors different names that are more descriptive than PA1-PA3. Factor One seems to describe the intensity of a song and a measurable amount of property, so I’ll rename Factor One to pa1_intensity (pa = principal axis and 1 = originally factor 1). Factor Two seems to describe level of involvement, which may be a little bit of a stretch, but involvement meaning the extent to which singers, instruments, and movement (i.e., dancing) contribute to a song. I’ll rename Factor Two to pa2_involvement. Finally, Factor Three is pretty basic and describe very technical aspects of songs, so I’ll rename Factor Three to pa3_technicality.

# renaming factors
d <- d %>% 
  rename("pa1_intensity" = "PA1",     # new column name = old column name
         "pa2_involvement" = "PA2", 
         "pa3_technicality" = "PA3") 

# checking work
names(d)

 [1] "track_id"                 "track_name"              
 [3] "track_artist"             "track_popularity"        
 [5] "track_album_id"           "track_album_name"        
 [7] "track_album_release_date" "playlist_name"           
 [9] "playlist_id"              "playlist_genre"          
[11] "playlist_subgenre"        "danceability"            
[13] "energy"                   "key"                     
[15] "loudness"                 "mode"                    
[17] "speechiness"              "acousticness"            
[19] "instrumentalness"         "liveness"                
[21] "valence"                  "tempo"                   
[23] "duration_ms"              "pa1_intensity"           
[25] "pa2_involvement"          "pa3_technicality"

title: 2  Methods: Brooke’s Spotify data variable creation
section: 2.4 Saving data file with new variables
text:
2.4 Saving data file with new variables

# creating a dataset that has a merge variable (track id) and my 3 new vars
new_vars <- d %>% 
  select(track_id, pa1_intensity, pa2_involvement, pa3_technicality)

# exporting the dataset
write.csv(new_vars, "Homework3_variables.csv")

title: 2  Methods: Brooke’s Spotify data variable creation
text:
2.2 Correlation matrix
Before running the EFA, first I examined a correlation matrix to see whether any of the variables have reasonable correlations.

Looking at the correlation matrix, it seems that loudness and energy are highly positively correlated (r = .68), valence and danceability are positively correlated (r = .33), acousticness and energy are negatively correlated (r = -.54), and acousticness and loudness are negatively correlated (r = -.36). There are a few other smaller correlations, but these are the main ones. I wonder if there could be two factors that relate to how upbeat or chill a song is.
In terms of outliers, it looks like duration in ms, mode, and key aren’t really correlated with much, but mode and key are correlated with each other. I think I’m going to eliminate duration in ms because I’m not sure that relates a ton to the other variables. I’ll keep mode and key! (Also I’m aware this is pretty arbitrary but I’m just going with it.)

title: 2  Methods: Brooke’s Spotify data variable creation
text:
2.3 Extracting factors
I’m going to use factor analysis to analyze covariance (rather than unique variance or error variance). I suspect there could be three factors, with one related songs that are upbeat, another with chill song characteristics, and a third with mode and key together (I’m not really a music person but maybe those have to do with the logistics/creation of a song).
To determine how many factors to extract, I could keep factors with an eigenvalue above 1.


 [1] 2.1522908 1.5192814 1.1795078 1.0892864 0.9786859 0.9729357 0.8700836
 [8] 0.8068100 0.6375606 0.5688131 0.2247446


Interestingly, there are four factors with an eigenvalue greater than 1. Let’s look at a Scree plot as well.





It appears there could be a couple elbows here. I guess one elbow could be the third factor, but the more obvious elbow is the fourth factor. Maybe I will try a solution with two factors and also four factors to see how well it fits.

2.3.1 Factor rotation
I think it’s fine for the factors to be correlated, so I’ll use an oblique rotation and retain 4 factors. Based on the eigenvalues alone (and kind of the Scree plot), this seems to be the best fit.
NOTE: I tested 2, 3, and 4 factors, and for the sake of the assignment to have three variables, I decided to go with 3 factors, so that is all I will show here.

# running the factor analysis - 3 factors
fa3 <- fa(r = cor_matrix2,      # Correlation matrix input
          nfactors = 3,         # Number of factors retained
          rotate = "oblimin",   # Type of rotation used, "oblimin" for "oblique"
          covar = FALSE,        # Type of input matrix (we're inputting a correlation matrix)
          fm = "pa",            # principal axis factoring
          max.iter = 500)       # increasing the maximum number of iterations than the default

title: 2  Methods: Brooke’s Spotify data variable creation
text:
2.4 Interpreting findings
I’m going to look at and interpret the results to see what is best. Typically we consider a strong enough link to be >0.30. I’ll also look at whether there’s any variables that load onto multiple factors or neither factors (the first of which being more problematic). Finally, we’ll look at interpretability and whether the factor extraction makes sense.
Also, h\(^2\) values represent the proportion of the variance in a variable that is predictable from the factors underlying it. If communality values equal or exceed 1, there is a problem (too little data, wrong number of factors extracted). A very low communality value for a variable indicates that this variable is an “outlier variable,” because it can’t be predicted from the factors extracted.


Factor Analysis using method =  pa
Call: fa(r = cor_matrix2, nfactors = 3, rotate = "oblimin", covar = FALSE, 
    max.iter = 500, fm = "pa")
Standardized loadings (pattern matrix) based upon correlation matrix
                 item   PA1   PA2   PA3    h2     u2 com
energy              2  1.02 -0.02  0.00 1.043 -0.043 1.0
loudness            4  0.67  0.07 -0.01 0.447  0.553 1.0
acousticness        7 -0.53 -0.02  0.00 0.282  0.718 1.0
liveness            9  0.14 -0.11 -0.03 0.034  0.966 2.0
danceability        1 -0.01  0.86  0.00 0.737  0.263 1.0
valence            10  0.13  0.40  0.04 0.172  0.828 1.2
speechiness         6  0.00  0.18 -0.08 0.043  0.957 1.4
tempo              11  0.15 -0.17  0.00 0.054  0.946 2.0
instrumentalness    8 -0.05 -0.12 -0.02 0.015  0.985 1.4
mode                5  0.00  0.00  0.65 0.419  0.581 1.0
key                 3  0.00  0.00 -0.27 0.071  0.929 1.0

                       PA1  PA2  PA3
SS loadings           1.83 0.99 0.50
Proportion Var        0.17 0.09 0.05
Cumulative Var        0.17 0.26 0.30
Proportion Explained  0.55 0.30 0.15
Cumulative Proportion 0.55 0.85 1.00

 With factor correlations of 
      PA1   PA2   PA3
PA1  1.00 -0.05 -0.01
PA2 -0.05  1.00 -0.10
PA3 -0.01 -0.10  1.00

Mean item complexity =  1.3
Test of the hypothesis that 3 factors are sufficient.

df null model =  55  with the objective function =  1.47
df of  the model are 25  and the objective function was  0.19 

The root mean square of the residuals (RMSR) is  0.04 
The df corrected root mean square of the residuals is  0.06 

Fit based upon off diagonal values = 0.94





Energy still has a very high h\(^2\) value and the only variables that really load onto the third factor are mode and key, which was predicted from the correlation matrix. Compared to the 2 factor solution, the three factor seems to be a better fit. On factor one is energy, loudness, and acousticness. Liveness and tempo kind of load onto both factors. For factor two, there is danceability, valence, speechiness, and instrumentalness. So far I think this solution is better than the two factor solution!
The three factor solution also fit better than the four factor solution. With the four factor solution, the h\(^2\) value was still high for energy, but also very high for instrumentalness (1.56) and danceability (2.42). I don’t think these factors are as interpretable. That said, I am going with the three factor solution.

title: 2  Methods: Brooke’s Spotify data variable creation
text:
2.5 Conclusion
I’ve decided based on interpretibility and factor loadings, I’m going to go with the three factor solution. This also works best with the assingment :) Finally, about 30% of the variance is being explained by 3 factors.

title: 2  Methods: Brooke’s Spotify data variable creation
text:
2.6 Factor scores
Next I’m going to create factor scores from the 3 factor model, which are estimates of the scores participants (songs in this case) would have received on each of the factors had the factors been measured directly. Factor scores weigh individual variables differently from one sample to the next and depend in part on the “other” variables that were included in the factor analysis.
R will automatically call them PA1, PA2, and PA3. They are stuck on the end of the dataset!

From this, I’m going to give the factors different names that are more descriptive than PA1-PA3. Factor One seems to describe the intensity of a song and a measurable amount of property, so I’ll rename Factor One to pa1_intensity (pa = principal axis and 1 = originally factor 1). Factor Two seems to describe level of involvement, which may be a little bit of a stretch, but involvement meaning the extent to which singers, instruments, and movement (i.e., dancing) contribute to a song. I’ll rename Factor Two to pa2_involvement. Finally, Factor Three is pretty basic and describe very technical aspects of songs, so I’ll rename Factor Three to pa3_technicality.
